title: Announcing the Transport Data Minihack 2026
text:
The Institute for Transport Studies (ITS) is excited to announce the Transport Data Minihack 2026, an event designed to foster data, coding, and reproducible research skills among ITS staff and students. This mini-hackathon provides a unique opportunity to delve into transport datasets, enhance technical abilities, and collaborate on real-world data challenges.
Scheduled for Thursday, May 7th, 2026, the event aims to create a supportive environment for participants, especially ITS MSc students working on their dissertation projects. It’s a chance to get hands-on support with importing, processing, and visualizing data, and to explore the power of data science techniques in the context of transport.



Supportive Learning: Provide a space for participants to ask questions about working with datasets and applying data science techniques to transport data.
Dissertation Assistance: Offer direct support for importing datasets for MSc dissertations and other research projects.
Data Wrangling: Focus on practical skills using tools like the tidyverse R package for data manipulation.
Data Visualization: Enhance general data visualization skills and gain specific experience with various transport data types.
Open Science Promotion: Showcase the potential of open data (transparency, participation, research) and reproducible/open workflows.




The Minihack is open to all staff and students at ITS. If you are not based at the University of Leeds but are interested in participating, please contact the organizers (Robin Lovelace) for more information.



The event will feature a structured yet flexible schedule to maximize learning and collaboration:

13:00 - 13:30: Introduction to importing, processing, and visualizing data with RStudio, including an overview of RStudio and Quarto for reproducible reports, and an example with origin-destination data in Leeds.
13:30 - 14:00: Dedicated time for importing datasets and installing necessary packages, with support available for any issues.
14:00 - 14:05: Short break.
14:05 - 15:00: Solo working sessions on datasets, with organizers available for questions and support.
15:15 - 15:45: Optional presentations of results, offering participants a chance to share their learnings.
15:45 - 16:00: Networking and idea-sharing session.




Participants will have the opportunity to win a copy of “Geocomputation with Python” or “Geocomputation with R (second edition)”. Prizes will be awarded based on:

Best technical implementation and code.
Most creative or impactful use of data.

Challenges for participants include writing code to automatically download and import datasets, subsetting data, and creating Quarto reports summarizing their analysis.
Don’t miss this opportunity to enhance your data skills and contribute to the vibrant research community at ITS! Sign-up details can be found here.

title: About — Data Science & Technology
text:
About the Data Science & Technology theme
The Data Science & Technology theme at the Institute for Transport Studies (ITS), University of Leeds brings together researchers working at the intersection of data science, machine learning, and transport systems.
Our mission is to develop methods and tools that improve transport planning, operations, and policy through better data, modelling, and technology.
Key focus areas include:

Mobility data science and analytics
Transport modelling and simulation
Machine learning for transport applications
Intelligent transport systems and automation
Spatial data science and networks

We collaborate across the University and with external partners to ensure our research has academic rigor and real-world impact.

title: Data Science and Technology
text:
Data Science and Technology (DST) is a theme within the Institute for Transport Studies at the University of Leeds that applies new digital technologies to answer research questions and inform decision-making in transport planning, operations, and policy. The theme brings together experts in data science, transport modelling, and the use of broadly-defined artificial intelligence techniques to address challenges in the transport sector. Although the focus is on new methods and technologies, our aim has an important social dimension: we believe in reducing barriers to accessing and using data and digital tools to improve transport systems for all users.
Our work covers a range of topics, including:

The application of data science techniques to transport research questions and applications
The development of transport methods, models, and tools to support better decision-making
The use of computer vision and other machine learning techniques to extract insights from transport-related datasets
The use of artificial intelligence to improve transport systems

title: Projects — Data Science & Technology
text:
Our theme members are involved in a wide range of research projects, often in collaboration with the Leeds Institute for Data Analytics (LIDA).


The PCT is a strategic planning tool for cycling infrastructure. It was designed to assist transport planners and policy makers to prioritise investments and interventions to promote cycling. The project involves open access models and has revolutionised strategic cycle planning in England and Wales.




The NPT.scot project develops open network planning tools to support better transport planning across Scotland, with a focus on accessibility, active travel, and low-carbon mobility options. The code is open source and available on GitHub. See more on the University of Leeds website.
Other projects: TBC.

title: Open Source Software
text:
The Data Science & Technology theme at ITS develops and maintains open source software tools for transport research, planning, and analysis. Our software is freely available and supports reproducible research and practical applications.





Website: www.pct.bike
Description: Strategic planning tool for cycling infrastructure used across England and Wales
Code: Open source R packages and web application





Website: npt.scot
Description: Open network planning tools for transport planning in Scotland
Focus: Accessibility, active travel, and low-carbon mobility




Our team develops and maintains several R packages for transport data science:


Sustainable Transport Planning with R
A package for solving common problems in transport planning and modelling, such as downloading and cleaning transport datasets, creating desire lines, and working with origin-destination data. (Hosted by rOpenSci but developed by ITS researchers).



Propensity to Cycle Tool Data
Functions to access and reproduce data from the Propensity to Cycle Tool (PCT), making the data more accessible for research and educational purposes.



Origin-Destination Data Analysis
An R package specifically designed for working with and manipulating origin-destination data, a core component of transport modelling.



Convert UK Transport Data to GTFS
A tool to convert UK transport data formats (like TransXchange and ATOC CIF) into the standard General Transit Feed Specification (GTFS) format.



Road Safety Data Analysis
An R package for working with UK road collision data from the STATS19 database.



OpenStreetMap Data Processing
Tools for downloading and processing OpenStreetMap data for transport analysis.






Open Transport Data List
A curated list of open transport datasets for research, teaching, and to save the world.



Transport Data Science
Materials for the Transport Data Science post-graduate module at the University of Leeds’ Institute for Transport Studies.



Reproducible Road Safety Research with R
A practical user manual (book) for conducting reproducible road safety research using R.



NTEM to OD Matrix Converter
Scripts to convert the National Trip Ends Model (NTEM) into an Origin-Destination (OD) Matrix.





We welcome contributions to our open source projects. Visit our GitHub repositories to get involved, report issues, or suggest improvements.



For questions about our software or collaboration opportunities, please contact us.

title: Setting Up a Quarto Website for Reproducible Research
text:
In the realm of scientific research, the importance of reproducibility and open collaboration cannot be overstated. Researchers are increasingly adopting tools that not only facilitate rigorous analysis but also enable transparent sharing of their work. Quarto, an open-source scientific and technical publishing system, stands out as an excellent platform for achieving these goals.
Quarto allows you to combine prose, executable code (from R, Python, Julia, and more), and outputs into a single document, which can then be rendered into various formats like HTML, PDF, and Word. This inherent capability for integrating code and narrative makes it a powerful tool for reproducible research. When your analysis code is embedded directly within your publication, others can easily inspect, verify, and even re-run your work, fostering trust and accelerating scientific progress.


Hosting your Quarto-based blog or website on platforms like GitHub Pages offers significant advantages for open collaboration:

Version Control: GitHub provides robust version control, allowing you to track every change to your content and code. This ensures transparency and makes it easy to revert to previous versions if needed.
Accessibility: Your research becomes globally accessible, breaking down barriers to knowledge sharing. Anyone with an internet connection can view your work, fostering a wider audience and potential collaborations.
Community Engagement: GitHub’s features, such as issues and pull requests, enable direct engagement with your audience. Readers can report issues, suggest improvements, or even contribute directly to your content and code.
Reproducible Environment: By including your Quarto project files and potentially environment management files (like renv.lock for R or requirements.txt for Python), you can help others recreate the exact computational environment used for your analysis, ensuring true reproducibility.




This blog post itself is built using Quarto, demonstrating the ease with which you can set up a dynamic and reproducible online presence. The process involves:

Initializing a Quarto Project: Starting with quarto create project to scaffold your website.
Structuring Your Content: Organizing your posts within a posts/ directory and defining a listing page (blog.qmd) to display them.
Configuring Metadata: Using _quarto.yml for site-wide settings and posts/_metadata.yml for common post options, including integration with comment systems like Utterances.
Writing Posts: Crafting your content in .qmd files, embedding code chunks, and leveraging Quarto’s rich features for scientific communication.




If you’re considering migrating an existing blog or website to Quarto, here are some valuable resources that detail the process:

Migrating a blog to Quarto: Reverse engineering HTML to Markdown by David Schoch: This post offers insights into converting existing HTML content to Markdown for Quarto.

https://blog.schochastics.net/posts/2024-01-02_migrating-to-quarto/

Migrating from blogdown/Hugo to Quarto by Ben Harrap: A practical guide focusing on URL consistency and R Markdown to Quarto conversion.

https://benharrap.com/post/2024-11-25-quarto-migration/

Reviving the blog with Quarto from the HoloViz blog: Discusses the rationale and process of migrating a Python-centric blog to Quarto.

https://blog.holoviz.org/posts/quarto_migration/

Porting a distill blog to quarto by Danielle Navarro: A detailed account of migrating from Distill, covering YAML changes and styling.

https://blog.djnavarro.net/posts/2022-04-20_porting-to-quarto/

Migrating this website from blogdown to Quarto by Monica Thieu: A general overview of the migration process, including handling executable code.

https://www.monicathieu.com/posts/2024-12-29-setting-up-this-website.html


By embracing Quarto and hosting your work on platforms like GitHub, you contribute to a more open, transparent, and collaborative scientific ecosystem.
